content.body_md:
Preface

Bridging Research, Industry, and Real-World AI

Advanced Machine Learning & Real-Time Deployment

Welcome to the Advanced Machine Learning and Real-Time Deployment course—an immersive program informed by years of hands-on work across academia and industry. This course bridges the gap between theoretical foundations and production-grade AI systems.

Having navigated both research and applied engineering, I understand the practical challenges of turning ideas into dependable, scalable solutions. This program helps you avoid common pitfalls, adopt best practices, and accelerate your ability to deploy AI that impacts real users and real businesses.

Your next step toward impactful innovation begins here.
What you’ll master
  • Production-ready coding patterns & modularity
  • Advanced SQL & data modeling for ML
  • Statistics that matter in practice
  • Unsupervised & supervised ML workflows
  • Real-time inference & deployment
  • Integrating AI APIs with cloud & databases
Who this is for
  • Engineers & analysts moving into applied ML
  • Researchers shipping real-world prototypes
  • Builders who value robust, maintainable systems
Roadmap (9 Weeks)
Week 1: Ice Breaker for Coding Week 2: UI & UX Week 3: Modularity Week 4: Advanced SQL Week 5: Stats for ML Week 6: Unsupervised ML Week 7: Supervised ML Week 8: Utilizing AI API Week 9: Capstone
Start Learning View Syllabus

lessons.title: Profile of the Tutor: Hawkar Abdulhaq

content.body_md:
Profile

Hawkar

PhD Candidate (Earth Sciences) — Geothermal & UTES • Groundwater Modeling • GeoScience Python

Place & Date of Birth: Erbil, Iraq, 1987

Current Program: PhD Candidate (Earth Sciences), University of Szeged (2021–Present)

Core Coding Stack
Python SQL HTML Server Deployment
Google Scholar Download CV
Engineering

Big-Data Acceleration & Production-Ready Pipelines

Prioritizing clean code, robust data engineering, and performance for geoscience scale

I design and ship data engineering pipelines that shrink processing time for large geoscience datasets (well logs, reservoir models, climate series). My focus is on modular code, reliable storage interfaces, and deployment-ready services that convert complex subsurface data into fast, trustable results.

What I Build
  • ETL/ELT pipelines for well logs & UTES datasets
  • Fast preprocessors for modeling & ML workflows
  • Batch + near-real-time data services
  • Clean APIs & lightweight UIs for results
How I Code
  • Modular Python packages & clear interfaces
  • SQL-first data modeling for scale
  • Deterministic jobs with logging & retries
  • Deployable services (server setups & configs)
Where It Helps
  • UTES site screening & thermal performance
  • Groundwater & basin modeling pipelines
  • Climate & erosion analysis at scale
  • Geostatistics for mapping & decisions
Coding Priorities
Performance Modularity Data Integrity Reproducibility Maintainability Deployability
Research

Selected Research — Descriptive Highlights

Condensed narratives of recent publications (coding impact emphasized)

Harnessing geothermal energy in Hungary (2026)

Geological Society, London, Special Publications 555 (1), SP555-2024-22 • Cited by: 7 • Authors: Szanyi, Kovács, Abdulhaq

Developed a reproducible data pipeline to unify geothermal datasets across regions and stratigraphic units, enabling consistent analysis for national-scale assessment. The coding emphasis was on modular ingestion and queryable outputs for decision support.

New structural findings in Bijeel-Aqra, Kurdistan (2025)

Journal of African Earth Sciences 230, 105729 • Cited by: 1 • Authors: Sissakian, Ghafur, Sherwani, Abdulhaq, Omer

Built SQL-driven mapping layers and Python utilities to integrate structural observations with hydrocarbon maturation indicators. The workflow improved turnaround time from raw field data to interpretable structural products for exploration.

ML model for sand-channel prediction for UTES (2025)

Energies 18 (16), 4230 • Authors: Abdulhaq, Geiger, Vass, Tóth, Bozsó, Szanyi

Engineered a well-log feature pipeline and evaluation harness that speeds up model iteration for sand-channel detection. The codebase emphasized reusability, stratified validation, and deployment-ready artifacts for UTES site selection.

Soil types & erosion in Iraq — critical discussion (2025)

Iraqi Bulletin of Geology and Mining 21 (1), 343-364 • Authors: Sissakian, Othman, Obaid, Abdulhaq

Consolidated heterogeneous soil surveys and climate records into a clean analytical dataset. Python + SQL routines reduced manual preprocessing and made comparative erosion analyses repeatable.

Predicting thermal performance of ATES in depleted clastics (2025)

Energies 18 (10), 2642 • Cited by: 2 • Authors: Abdulhaq, Geiger, Vass, Tóth, Medgyes, Bozsó, Kóbor, …

Implemented a scalable training pipeline for thermal response prediction with configuration-based runs. Focus on dataset versioning, feature provenance, and efficient retraining for scenario testing.

Transforming abandoned fields into heat-storage sites (2024)

Energies 17 (16), 3954 • Cited by: 7 • Authors: Abdulhaq, Geiger, Vass, Tóth, Medgyes, Szanyi

Coded an enhanced MCDA-AHP workflow with geostatistical layers to rank storage candidates. Emphasis on transparent, scriptable criteria and reproducible maps for stakeholders.

Geothermal energy & critical metals — review (2023)

Energies 16 (20), 7168 • Cited by: 20 • Authors: Szanyi, Rybach, Abdulhaq

Assembled a curated literature dataset with standardized tags for rapid topic queries. Lightweight Python tooling aided evidence synthesis across sub-disciplines.

View All on Google Scholar Back to Research
Background

Education

Foundational training across geology, earth science engineering, and doctoral research

PhD Candidate (Earth Sciences)
University of Szeged — 2021–Present
MSc in Earth Science Engineering
University of Miskolc, Hungary — 2017
BSc in Geology
University of Salahadeen, Erbil — 2011
Teaching

Mentoring Philosophy

Committed to learner success and impact

“Whoever I mentor, I genuinely wish them great success, hoping they will achieve even greater success through this course.”
About

Bio

Academic rigor, industry practice, real-world outcomes

Hawkar combines rigorous academic training with hands-on industry experience, guiding learners to transform theoretical knowledge into impactful, real-world AI and data-driven solutions across geoscience domains. Work spans geothermal energy and underground thermal energy storage (UTES), groundwater modeling, climate analysis, geological mapping, and Python-based analytics for subsurface datasets.

© Hawkar Last updated

lessons.title: Four Levels of Using Generative AI

content.body_md:
Framework

Four Levels of Using Generative AI

From quick advice to strategic, production-grade AI systems

This practical framework explains how Generative AI can be applied at four maturity levels. As goals move from quick answers to end-to-end systems, the role of AI shifts—from a conversational consultant to a strategic asset embedded in products and research. This course emphasizes the top tiers so you can build, deploy, and operate solutions that matter.

Course Focus
Level 3 — Development Partner Level 4 — Strategic Asset
Levels

The Four Levels

Clear roles, purposes, output expectations, and real examples

1. AI as a Consultant

Role of GenAI
Conversational Q&A for quick advice
Purpose
Speed up understanding; get suggestions fast
Output
May contain inaccuracies — human validation required
Examples
  • Ask ChatGPT to debug a Python error or Excel formula
  • Request résumé-writing tips
  • Get high-level business-strategy pointers

2. AI as a Content Creator

Role of GenAI
Co-create text, images, video, or slides
Purpose
You set direction; AI drafts, polishes, and refines
Output
Aligned to your prompt and brand with review
Examples
  • Generate illustrations with DALL·E or Midjourney from your concept sketch
  • Draft a blog post in ChatGPT, then edit for brand voice
  • Produce a video script outline with AI-suggested structure

3. AI as a Development Partner

Role of GenAI
Python-driven data analysis, UI/UX, and real-time apps
Purpose
Accelerate developer workflows; scaffold scalable solutions
Output
Production-lean code with human architecture & reviews
Examples
  • Use GenAI to generate Python functions for data cleaning & feature engineering
  • Build an interactive Streamlit dashboard that summarizes KPIs and suggests visual improvements
  • Auto-scaffold REST API endpoints with FastAPI to serve data insights
  • Get AI-guided UI mock-ups or CSS tweaks that enhance user experience

4. AI as a Strategic Asset

Role of GenAI
ML deployment, predictive models, and deep integration
Purpose
Embed AI into products, operations, or research outputs
Output
End-to-end ML systems with monitoring & governance
Examples
  • Deploy a GenAI-assisted sales-forecasting model with live monitoring
  • Integrate a recommendation engine into an e-commerce platform for personalized offers
  • Publish research using GenAI-driven climate or geothermal predictions
  • Build a chat-based analytics assistant over corporate data with a RAG pipeline
Focus on Levels 3 & 4 Back to Top
Course Focus

Build • Deploy • Leverage

Zeroing in on Levels 3 & 4 for real-world impact

Learn to elevate GenAI from an ideation aid to a development partner and ultimately a strategic asset. We cover production-lean Python patterns, scalable data services, UI/UX scaffolding, deployment playbooks, and monitoring that keeps models accountable in the wild.

What You’ll Practice
Python & APIs Data Engineering RAG & Retrieval Model Serving Observability UX for AI
Start Learning Back to Top

Lifestyle

Adopting AI as a Lifestyle

Integrating AI into your daily life boosts productivity—if done sustainably

Here are four science-backed strategies for integrating AI into your routine in ways that maximize productivity while keeping your energy sustainable.

Step 1

Block Out Distraction-Free Time

Silence notifications and dedicate sessions for uninterrupted deep work.

Why? Research shows it takes 23 minutes to refocus after interruptions (Mark, Gudith, & Klocke, 2008).

Mark et al., 2008
“Deep work is professional activity performed in a state of distraction-free concentration. It pushes your cognitive capabilities to their limit, creating new value and improving your skills.” Newport, 2016
Step 2

Break Tasks Into Manageable Steps

Use ChatGPT to break large AI projects into clear subtasks. Track progress in a checklist (like Google Sheets), marking items complete.

Why? According to psychologist Dr. Timothy Pychyl:

“Breaking tasks down reduces procrastination by decreasing uncertainty and anxiety about where to start.”

Marking tasks complete also releases dopamine, boosting motivation and productivity (Gawande, 2009).

Gawande, 2009
Step 3

Schedule Regular Recharge Breaks

Take frequent short breaks away from screens—walk, stretch, or get fresh air.

Why? Stanford researchers found walking increases creative thinking by ~60% compared to sitting (Oppezzo & Schwartz, 2014).

Oppezzo & Schwartz, 2014

Breaks also help sustain focus and prevent burnout, improving long-term productivity (Ariga & Lleras, 2011).

Ariga & Lleras, 2011
Step 4

Seek Alternative Perspectives

When stuck, consult ChatGPT or peers for fresh approaches. Reframe the problem by stepping back to view the broader context.

Why? Innovation experts suggest that:

“Reframing problems generates novel solutions by challenging initial assumptions.” Grant, 2021

Studies also show AI like ChatGPT can boost creativity by ~15%, providing insights differently from traditional methods (Kohnke, 2023).

Kohnke, 2023
Closing

Sustainable Progress

“Sustainable progress beats burnout. Keep your energy high by balancing focused work with well-timed breaks.”

Wishing you a productive and healthy AI journey!

© Hawkar — Last updated

lessons.title: What is Python? Why We Chose It for Learning!

content.body_md:
Section 1.3

What is Python? Why We Chose It for Learning!

A language built for readability, versatility, and real-world impact

Python is a powerful, high-level programming language celebrated for its readability and versatility. From web development to scientific research, its clean, intuitive syntax makes it a favorite for both beginners and experts.

Essentials

Why Python is Ideal for Learning

Ease of Learning – Syntax resembles human language; beginner-friendly.
Wide Application – Powers data analysis, ML, web apps, automation, and more.
Strong Community Support – Large ecosystem of libraries, frameworks, and help.
Career Relevance – Highly sought after in data science, AI, web, and beyond.
Applications

Python’s Applications Across Fields

Geosciences

Earthquake analysis, climate modeling, geological surveys. Libraries like GeoPandas and GDAL analyze spatial data; USGS API delivers real-time data.

Medical & Health Sciences

Image analysis, patient data, drug discovery. SimpleITK and OpenCV process X-rays and MRIs, accelerating diagnoses.

Finance

Algorithmic trading, risk assessment, fraud detection. Pandas and NumPy manage datasets; Scikit-Learn powers stock predictions.

Education

Performance analysis, grading automation, interactive apps. Jupyter Notebooks deliver lessons and let students practice coding.

Engineering & Manufacturing

Process simulation, design optimization, production-line management. SciPy and Matplotlib model and visualize systems.

Entertainment & Media

Game dev, animation, content recommendations. Pygame supports games; TensorFlow/Keras enable personalization.

Agriculture

Crop-yield prediction, soil health, pest detection. Remote sensing + NDVI libraries analyze plant health for decisions.

Resources

More References

GeeksforGeeks – Python Applications in Real World Bocasay – 7 Applications of Python Programming Trio – Python Applications
© Hawkar — Last updated

lessons.title: What is in the Python Script?

content.body_md:
Python Basics

A Python Script Explained

Libraries, variables, functions, loops, and outputs working together

A Python script is a collection of libraries, variables, functions, and loops that create a structured workflow. Think of it like a recipe: each line is an instruction that moves the task toward completion.

Essentials

Key Components of a Script

Importing Libraries

Adds pre-built functionality (data handling, plotting, web access, etc.).

import pandas as pd

Defining Variables

Stores information (numbers, text) for later use.

temperature = 72

Functions & Loops

Reusable tasks and repeated actions, reducing code repetition.

for item in list:

Data Processing & Analysis

Cleans, calculates, and organizes data for insights.

# Calculate averages, clean missing values

Output & Visualization

Displays results—print statements, charts, or saved files.

print("Average =", avg)
Example

End-to-End Python Script

Here’s a simple script that processes and visualizes weather data:

# 1. Importing Libraries
import pandas as pd           # Manage and analyze data tables
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt  # Create visualizations

# 2. Defining Variables
data = {
    "Temperature": [70, 75, 80, 85, 90],
    "Humidity":    [30, 45, 50, 60, 70],
}
city = "Kurdistan"

# 3. DataFrame & Average Temperature
df = pd.DataFrame(data)
average_temp = df["Temperature"].mean()

# 4. Loop through Data and Print
print(f"Weather data for {city}:")
for temp in df["Temperature"]:
    print(f"- Temperature: {temp}°F")

# 5. Visualize Data
plt.plot(df["Temperature"], label="Temperature", color="red")
plt.plot(df["Humidity"], label="Humidity", color="blue")
plt.xlabel("Day")
plt.ylabel("Value")
plt.title(f"Weather Data for {city}")
plt.legend()
plt.show()

# 6. Output Result
print(f"The average temperature in {city} is {average_temp}°F.")
© Hawkar — Last updated

Reference

Python Libraries — Quick Reference

Core libraries, purposes, and example projects — with context

Python libraries extend the language’s functionality so you can solve complex problems with concise, reliable code. Use this list as a practical starting point when choosing tools for data, web, ML, and apps.

How to choose: Start from the purpose column. If you need tabular data work, reach for Pandas; interactive charts? Try Plotly; production web? Flask or Django depending on scope.
Tip: Combine a small set well (e.g., Pandas + NumPy + Matplotlib) before adding more. Fewer dependencies = simpler deployments.
Catalog

Core Libraries at a Glance

Purpose-first overview with concrete examples

# Library Purpose Example Projects
0 Pandas Data manipulation & analysis Clean and analyze CSV/Excel, process financial data, generate reports
1 NumPy Numerical computing, matrix operations Scientific computing, large datasets, linear algebra
2 Matplotlib Static visualizations & charts Line, bar, pie charts; trend plotting
3 Seaborn Statistical data visualization Heatmaps, pair plots, exploratory data reports
4 Scikit-Learn Machine-learning models Classification, clustering, recommendation engines
5 TensorFlow Deep-learning & neural networks Image recognition, object detection, NLP
6 Keras Rapid deep-learning prototyping Quick image or text models for experimentation
7 NLTK Basic NLP & text processing Chatbots, sentiment analysis, language translation
8 spaCy Advanced NLP at scale Entity recognition, document classification, large language models
9 OpenCV Computer vision Face recognition, motion tracking, real-time object detection
10 BeautifulSoup Web scraping Collect news articles, aggregate multi-site data
11 Requests HTTP requests & API access Retrieve weather data, stock quotes, automate REST calls
12 Flask Lightweight web apps / REST APIs Rapid dashboards, microservices, prototypes
13 Django Full-stack web framework E-commerce sites, CMS platforms, large web apps
14 Streamlit Interactive data apps & dashboards No-boilerplate dashboards, data visualizations
15 Pygame 2D game development Educational games, interactive simulations
16 PySpark Distributed data processing Big-data analytics, real-time ETL pipelines
17 Plotly Interactive web visuals 3D graphs, dynamic dashboards, browser-based charts
18 SQLAlchemy Database ORM & management CRUD backends, database migrations, data models
© Hawkar — Last updated
